author: {'steamid': '76561198427181741', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 168, 'playtime_at_review': 3712, 'last_played': 1712408901}
review:
我也是老玩家了，之前在手机上玩，一玩就是好几个小时很上头。总之就是很推荐，回合制的海战，可以自己编辑武器，编辑自己的舰队形成不同的战斗风格，优点很多就不一一讲了。主要说一下缺点：
1，没有中文，对于游戏游玩问题不大，多摸索摸索查一查关键单词就可以了，但是我更想知道舰船的名称这样会更有感觉。
2，船体模型单一，无论是英军，美军，德军等等都是用的一套船的模型，建议可以增加以及不同国家的船模型，例如美国的就可以以北卡或者衣阿华为模型，英国可以用乔治五世级，德国可以用格奈森瑙，俾斯麦等等。
3，难度跨度稍微有点大，打中等难度乱打，玩最高难度被乱打。
4，可以优化一下舰长系统。
5，开局不能布置船的位置有点伤，全是随机的，有些地图地形有点难受，他恰好又给你分兵，又把航母布置在极为阴间的位置。
6，船太少了，准确的说是船的模板太少了，作为一个战舰世界玩家，战舰不止有CV，BB，CA，DD，等等，航母可以分成护航航母（如博格）和那种大的航母（如埃塞克斯，翔鹤等等），战列舰也有条约型，高速战列舰，战列巡洋舰和一些老式的无畏舰等等，巡洋也有轻重之分。建议可以多加几个不同的模板。
7，武器太少了，就以战列舰为例即使不分口径他也只有三联装主炮，双联装和四联装没有体现，巡洋舰也是一样的，只有双联装，没有三联装和单门火炮，副炮和鱼雷就更不用说了，没有体现阵营特色（比如可以增加日系鱼雷射程和威力，增加德系副炮射程，增强美系两用炮的效率等）。
8，地图可以稍微做大一点点，无论是总的大地图和作战小地图，大地图方面一个格子感觉跨度稍大，可以多划分几格，小地图也可以做大，不然还没有排兵布阵就打起来了，此外，这对航母也不公平，开局2回合就处于对方战列舰射程之内了。
9，最后，可以增加天气系统，优化海平面与岛屿，增加一些特别舰种和一些战术卡片。

review: Very realistic, fun, and strategic. I enjoy the level up system, I feel there's more they could add to this game though, such as but not limited to; a co-operative mode either with online or hotseat so you can fight the AI with your friends. They could also add more achievements, and even steam trading cards. But as I stated good game, and I really enjoy not only that strategy of this game, but also the realism. There is a bug that could be worked out, sometimes the game won't register that a ship has hit 0% health so you have to waste one more ammunition to sink it and it can cost you, your ships life. For example in one ships turn I used up all my ammunition on a cruiser to get the enemy battleship to 0% health and somehow the mf was still floating, dude clearly had no health left, that same mf sunk my cruiser immediately after I ended my turn, it pissed me off. I have also come to find that this game shows just how important the key turning points were during the second world war. In the Atlantic campaign I feel like whoever knocks out the main force first, and captures the entire English, & Mediterranean, channels the quickest. pretty much achieves victory, for the entire war/campaign. In the pacific the key points kinda vary, but I have found the key points to commonly be the islands that line up towards Japan and that area. That and the sea zones around the Alaska/Canada, and the Australia/New Zealand, areas. Or at least that's what the AI seems to favorite in my experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971288377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1640459821}
review:
Starts off as a great WW2 naval simulator, but the problems start to become apparent after a few hours of gameplay.

- The AI isn't very smart.  It has a tendency to keep attacking the same position over and over again, losing badly each time before retreating.  (Retreating costs you half your ships).  After 4 or 5 repetitions of this, you can steamroll the map without much issue.
- When you enter battle mode, your ships are apparently randomly placed.  This makes zero tactical sense and can actually cost you the battle if your key ships end up too close to the enemy fortifications (Seriously, what the hell was the dev thinking here??)
- The primary effect of increasing the difficulty level is to reduce the number of targeting reticles you have to help figure out ranges.  This is not adding actual difficulty in the least.  Frankly, I was hoping this game would include radar as it was available in primitive form in the Pacific theater, so rangefinding manually to begin with is a bit archaic.  (And tedious)
- Battleships are weaker than you might expect and can be disabled by even a small enemy fleet if they get lucky.  The only actual way to defeat a battleship is to overwhelm it with a large fleet or from a safe distance using airstrikes.
- I have seen a single ship turn away an airstrike due to having enough AA capability - it takes an entire fleet to do this, a single ship cannot in any circumstance.
- The game needs a keyboard shortcut to skip a given ship's turn.  While we're at it, there needs to be a toggle to autoskip all transports; they're almost worthless in battle and I never found a situation where I actually needed to move one unless it was in the way.
- There is no differentiation between ship classes.  A destroyer is a destroyer, a battleship is a battleship.  Cruisers are cruisers, forget about CLs vs CAs.  This oversimplification kills a lot of nuance, as any WW2 buff knows that an Iowa class battleship and an Arkansas class battleship are quite different in terms of their capabilities.

Due to these issues, I cannot recommmend this game at any price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031382145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1625082632}
review:
A pretty cool, if simple, strategy game. The interface is pretty clean and easy to use. Finding the range for the guns takes practise and doesn't always seem consistent - I have learned that the range you select is were shells would drop into the water, but since ships have height, aim further out to get a nice solid hit on them. A sub, however, being lower, needs more accuracy and you want the shells to drop right onto it, so aim for its exact location.

Frigates seem pretty useless due to being very lightweight. So do submarines, because they travel so slowly that often the engagement is over before they can reach a target. They are very hampered around islands because of their small turning circle, so best used in open sea or for defence. Once on target, those two torpedos inflict serious damage - but actually getting your sub into range is tricky.

Carriers are good in the early campaign, but as soon as the AI gets a decent air defence, their use is limited because flights get taken down easily. Their only use then is recon - and cruisers do that just as well. Having said that, a carrier with decent XP can take out land-based artillery in one or two raids. And THAT is VERY useful when taking an island. It's that or battleships - and the land artillery has the same range as a battleship. So a couple of good carriers will make a huge difference in the final stages.

Cruisers are awesome for their firepower, but battleships are even better. That is the strongest unit in the game, with guns which have the longest range. And range is important, here. Being able to shoot without being in range oneself is a huge advantage.

Drawbacks: it's a bit easy. I completed the entire first campaign on my first try, and had overwhelming firepower by the final battle. I needed only one of the two massive fleets I had created (one out of Hawaii, one out of Australia) and I don't think I took a single loss to my fleet in the final battle. Carriers took care of the land-base artillery in the first 3 turns, and my battleships made short work of the cruisers and then the airbase.

The AI is very poor at aiming, so all else being equal, two ships of equal capabilities facing off should see the human player win with very little difficulty. The AI also has no discernible strategy other than "move towards the opponent and fire when in range" - unless vastly outnumbered, when it hides in a corner.

Having groups of ships sail together is an obvious advantage with the combined firepower - but the AI just ignores that. It is also a problem when you first enter an area. The AI deploys your ships for you, however it sees fit. I cannot spot a pattern, but I want destroyers with my ships because they can spot submarines. But it's quite possible that your two destroyers will be deployed half way over the map to the rest of your fleet, making the others very vulnerable. Luckily, the AI only used a few subs against me. Not being able to set up your own line of battle is a huge strategic disappointment in the game. In real life, the Admiral in charge would have had maps of the target area, and would have sailed there in good order, to line up as per his battle plan. There really is no need to randomly scatter the player's forces over the map.

It shouldn't be too hard to allow the player to drag and drop their ships, or to provide a few standard formations. Or, even, to group all the player's ships together in good order by default, instead of spreading them out. As it stands, and because of the way turns work (ships with higher XP moving first) it is quite possible to ram one of your own ships by mistake on the initial moves, simply by ordering them to go straight ahead and at full speed.

Ships do not move realistically, either. You give the rudder a direction and an amount of power, and they move accordingly - then halt. One turn might be full speed ahead, and the other turn full reverse. There is no wave movement, or wind to take into account. Aim your guns, give a distance and your shells will always drop exactly where expected. This is really OP, because on (say) a battleship, one can use one smaller gun to range-find the enemy and then use the other 2 side-guns to batter it with 2 shells per gun, before moving onto the two big guns and battering it with them, too. The only adjustments needed will be slight angle changes as you switch between guns and maybe a little distance.

There's also a weird "levelling up" system. For some reason, one cannot buy all the ship types at the start of the game. They become unlocked gradually. That's very odd. "Sorry, Admiral, we cannot let you order a new Carrier before you have engaged the Japanese a few times" really makes no sense. 

(Edit: reading another review, I learned that the locks can be disabled in the options - that would have been handy to know up-front. I remain at a loss at to what a "level" means, though)


There are also some rather odd sparkley things in the sea. If you sail over them, you get a special "card", like in a board game. I got a "free reconnasance flight anywhere on the map". But there was no discernable way to use it, and I had enough carriers and cruisers anyway.

Plus, by that time in the battle, I could see pretty much the entire map due to line of sight of my ships, and I knew where all my targets were. It's a strange addition which adds nothing of value.

It is by no means a challenging game. It is not a detailed simulation. It is not realistic. But it is a fun way to while away a few hours. I grabbed it on sale and I am quite happy with the VFM that I got. In a couple of days I will try the Atlantic campaign, too. I will take to this game once in a while when I have a couple of hours to kill and don't feel like being hugely challenged. Played like that, I think this game will be one to which I return often.

I couldn't for the life of me find a comfortable way to be in the sea with the boats, but it was pretty cool to visualize playing out.

I moved around, zoomed in & out, attempted some turns with my boats, and it crashed. I could see some potential fun in VR but mostly it's just a random game in my library that I found difficult to get going in. I also think maybe playing out of VR first would help.

review:
I just bought this 2 days ago and I really like this little number.

Pros:
+ easy to see what the game will be like before buying.  (a) strategic map giving context to individual battles (b) Worms-style individual battles
+ battle system good - a lot of sensible things happen e.g a shot lands in the water just next to the ship, it damages the ship a little, an extra 3 metres away it doesn't.  Or the fact that when a ship is hit, weapons can be damaged or the hull damaged - both will weaken the ship but sometimes a very weak enemy will still have all weapons firing and therefore be very dangerous (a near dead battleship destroyed a fullhealth destroyer of mine and nearly took out a 2nd before I learnt this lesson...).
+ some depth in choosing ship combos and favourite weapons aside from manoeuvring ships.  Torpedos have a short range but boy do they hurt.
+ responsive and active dev

Cons:
- battles can be a little slow for some and enjoyment seems to depend on whether you like angles/numbers.  I do.  If you don't, give this game a miss.
- strategic map could have extra layers to make it more like a Total War game e.g. building various buildings that unlock more powerful ships etc

Overall: 8.5/10 - simple game, but does it well.

review:
Good game!  
- Satisfying combat
- A good assortment of historical ship types
- Challenges both historical and tactical

Not perfect though:
- A lot of simplifications were made for game balance purposes, so don't expect a high level of authenticity.  Naval historians may cringe from time to time.
- The "Unlock" system is how the game forces you to "learn" by proceeding through increasingly complex battles until you "earn" the right to build certain ship types.  However, it's not hard to go through the battles on medium difficulty level, and to unlock the most valuable stuff takes only a few hours of gameplay.  I honestly did not mind going through it.

Overall, it's a good balance between historical realism, decent graphics and quick-and-easy combat.  I look forward to further efforts along these lines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057058810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1333, 'last_played': 1532687186}
review:
[Inserting edit line here to state 3D VR version is MUCH better than 2D non-VR. Started with VR 1st and almost had to learn how to gauge distances / aim all over again trying 2D]

TD:LR: Fun / engaging God mode / top down WW2 Battleship mainly artillery fire strategy game that has decent VR graphics (using HTC Vive). 

To be honest as a long time strategy / war game lover but short time VR'er....originally the thought of doing strategy game in VR seemed like something that would be fairly lame in comparison to high detail & resolution monitor viewing? To my surprise this BF2 is engaging and fun TBS strategy game in VR. FIrst right off the bat...If you suck at judging distances for artillery fire then this might be frustrating to you. Majority of the fire power is floating or fixed artillery and you have to basically dial in distance estimates (vs. cannon elevation to reach those distances). Think Worms games...but only in setting of god mode above battleships of WW2. It's not overly complex but must be able to judge distances. If you're WW2 war game fan, this game has enough detail that is engaging but not mired in history report. If you target parts of ships correctly, you can damage specific areas and zoom in far enough and see matching visual damage. There's a bit of grand strategy in the campaign mode as you have to shift around fleets to create / combine them, attack enemy and still defend territories. But mostly it's TBS battle map strategy.

Game does have some room for improvement:
- It was designed for you to stand and play in VR. Which is lame because if you could set the viewing height yourself, you could easily play it sitting down too. But because of limited clarity of VR text + game has stuff on drawing boards at upward angle can make  hard to read some of text....unless you stand and center your goggles. This is bad design flaw for VR'ing. 
- Campaign starting battle  layout is predetermined by Ai. This can be lame as you're best / slowest ships can be placed completely exposed to enemy fire w/o any means to you to initially protect them. They can also be placed far out of range and put rest of fleet at stand still to wait for them to catch up. Even if it would be too difficult to program basic Battleships board game layout choice, should be able to make some type of rudimentary fleet layout choice but there's nothing?
- Worst game flaw can be show stopper. Ship tracks are not shown at all, except wakes after-choice-has-been-made visuals. Sometimes in start of that Ai pre-determined fleet layout it stacks them VERY CLOSE. Different ships have different speed and turning radiuses. You will eventually have at least 2 ships collide because you can't eyeball guess correct speed + turning radius for every ship you can possibly have. Yes..that cute little frigate can cripple your mighty warship by just running into back of it. There really should be some type of track line that lays down so you can make sure your ships won't strike each other. Understand they did this for "realism" but real ships have quartermasters that plot out ship's course on paper so that doesnt happen. 
- Combine that plus campaign mode is perma-death / ironman. So ya just accidentally rammed your bestest ship. Well, ya did a save so you can just quit and start over right? Nope. You quit and auto lose 1/2 your fleet in that battle. And it doesnt matter if you Steam VR exit out of the game. Basically, you cripple on or start your campain over again... Can be bit frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034907165', 'num_games_owned': 1452, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1685, 'last_played': 1590303521}
review:
This is a nicely done timesink, better than I thought initially. I would say it's a good blend of accessability and reasonable depth. There is the obvious fire control, where you must find the correct bearing and range for your guns, but also a whole lot of other aspects to take into consideration. Easy to get into, but still deep enough to keep it interesting.

On a tactical level, you need to also move your ships in a tactically sound fashion to bring them into range, and even more importantly maneuver them to optimize the amount of gun turrets and torpedo launchers of your ships to be able participate in the exchange of volleys. The tactical map also contains some special areas which when taken produce special cards granting you different abilities to use in the battle, like extra recon flights, air strikes, field repairs, range finders etc. 

You can also perform ship refitting between battles, where you can change the weapons of your choosing for each individual ship (with restraints of the weapon slot provided by the ship class) to suit your taste and style of play. Similar kind of refitting is also possible when building new ships either in custom battles or campaign dock regions. 

This brings in the strategic layer, which is a bit thin but still there. In campaign mode you must decide which regions to defend, which to possibly forfeit and which to aim your invasions into. The regions with dock facilities enable you to spend your industrial points on building new ships, and the regions may also contain airfields and shore batteries to help you defend them. Every region also produces a certain amount of industrial points per turn.

The only real grievance I have so far with this game is the locking system, with puts part of the content behind an xp barrier, requiring you to fight a certain amount of battles for XP to unlock maps, game modes, ships, weaponry etc. It feels kind of silly to first do a quick battle to be able to start the first campaign, and then realize your ability to produce ships different classes is restricted to only a few of the smallest classes until your XP warrants more. All this while the AI seems to be happily churning out ships of every class. It's still an obstacle that can be overcome by grinding, but certainly feels unnecessary.

review:
Aside from the near fatal flaws in the campaign system (eg you can attack from west of a zone, and have your ships start the battle on the extreme east edge...) and the complete inability to set up any sort of formation for your fleets (ships are always placed randomly), it can be fun.

  Unfortunately, if you do get a battle in a campaign that is screwed up, it can (and does) completely ruin a campaign, no matter how long you have played. This is amplified by the fact that it auto saves after a fuked up set up and the only way to recover is to start a new camapign...

  If you don't mind this BS, then the game is fun.

  Just expect that your campaigns are a roll of the dice - you may be lucky and have no problems, or you may get screwed in any battle. If this happens to wipe out 5 or 6 turns of campaign production, lucky you!

review:
Je suis toujours à la recherche d'une simulation de bataille navale qui me satisfasse.

Ceci n'est pas une simulation, juste un jeu d'arcade.

Ce qui me déplait :

-- Système de visée inexistant (vous tirez au pif), avec des portées débiles (bon, on touche souvent).
-- Gestion des torpilles (c'est juste une plaisanterie, impossible à éviter) n'importenawak ! Faut juste pas se planter avec la portée...
-- Les vaisseaux, ouais bof, pas les plus beaux que j'ai vu (rien à voir avec Atlantic Fleet, bien meilleur et pas cher non plus !)
-- Système de déplacement pourri. On sais pas où on va, du coup on se rentre dedans. Une courbe de prévision de course, c'est si difficile à programmer ?

Ce qui pourrait être intéressant :

-- Reste un mode campagne qui n'est pas trop mal et donne un peu de relief au jeu.
-- La possibilité d'améliorer les navires, mais c'est assez limité.

Si vous cherchez une simulation un rien vraisemblable, passez votre chemin ! Sinon, comme jeu d'arcade navale, ça peut aller.

Bref pas cher, mais pas terrible !

Je mets néanmoins un avis favorable au vu du prix et du mode campagne, qui rattrape pas mal le jeu.

review:
[h1]Краткий отзыв, первое впечатление.[/h1]

[b]Pro ...[/b] 

1. [i]Battle Fleet 2[/i] очень похож на [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i], но здесь есть многопользовательская игра.
2. Разведка. В [i]Battle Fleet 2[/i] играет значительную роль, как на стратегической карте, так и непосредственно в бою. В [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] разведки нет, хотя это и реалистично на предлагаемых дистанциях. 
3. Как и [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] игра чертовски проста в освоении, но тем не менее имеет глубокие и разносторонние игровые механики. 

[b]... et contra[/b]

Соответственно все минусы происходят от сравнения с [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i].

1. Не такой-то графон, и это при том, что обе игры, это порт с ведра, но [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] на ПК выглядит просто отлично и её не стыдно показать даже другу Коле, который котирует исключительно AAA YOBA games.
2. Модель повреждений. Да, она есть, можно выводить из строя разные узлы и элементы корабля, но с другой стороны имеем натуральную полоску хэпэ, которую увлекательно пилим, самым классическим образом. В [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] все хэпэ так ловко спрятаны в модель повреждений, что о них и не догадываешься. В целом модель повреждений в [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] намного сложнее, например корабли с течью дают определённый крен и т.п.
3. В [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] более интересно реализована работа авиации с авианесущих кораблей.
4. В [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] более интересно реализованы подводные лодки.

Тем не менее, пока в [i]Atlantic Fleet[/i] нет (и не предвидется) многопользовательской игры, для тех, кому, как и мне этот пункт более чем важен я бы рекомендовал обратить внимание на [i]Battle Fleet 2[/i].

review:
If you like turn based games, then this is one you should definitely get.  I played it using the HTC Vive VR system and the detail and user interface is incredible.  I spend the game standing waist deep in the ocean surrounded by my fleet and I can zoom all the way in to where I am standing next to the ship or zoom out as if I'm looking down from a high-altitude plane.  This is the old Battleship board game (H9, I7, "...you sunk my battleship!...") on steroids.  Instead of just point and shoot you have to gauge distance for each shot you take and have a mix of warships, including the aircraft carrier with fighter/bomber planes.  I setup my attack and then stand next to the ship I'm attacking fully zoomed-in so I can see the hit.  After enough hits, the ships start showing visible damage and flames / smoke / disabled guns or rudders, etc.  

The game contains a Campaign mode, which I don't have the time to play but which looks fun, and customizable single and multiplayer games where you can select the map and ships and even the guns on each of your ships.  The multiplayer is originally locked but I emailed the developer who replied within a day and who unlocked the multiplayer plus everything else in the game, per my request.  This alone warrants a second look at the game if you haven't already bought it.

The only suggestions that I would have for this game are to have more visible damage (ie - visible damage after every hit) and land based attacks (ie - destroy ports or coastal forts/entrenchments with your fleet)

On a related note, I also read this developer is working on a land-based game, so it'll be interesting to see what's involved in that game whenever it is released.

review:
This game is absolutely awesome.

I'm playing it in VR. 
Though the graphics are pretty simple, this is a super hard turn based strategy game and there's not enough of that in VR.

If you're craving something turn based, this will provide you hours and hours of fun.

The game seems to be extremely long compared to most VR games with multiple campaigns and lots of stuff to unlock.

Don't listen to the negative reviews.
People seem to be complaining about things being locked at first, but if it were all unlocked right at the beginning, the game would be too easy.

review:
Update: Changed Review from Negative to Positive
Reason: Developer responded to main critisism and added in the option to remove the gating system to the game.  Original review unchanged so you can decide for yourself. 

Other: They have also removed turn cool down on larger guns that I am not sure yet if I like or not.  

Summary: 
Good turn based naval game ruined by a pointless (new) gate/unlock system. If you can live with the unlock system, then it could be worth a shot. 

In Depth
Used to play this game, it was a fun turn based naval game with a good amount of tactical flexibility in the ship upgrade system.  

Alas imagine my surprise when I came back and everything is now "locked" behind some form of arbitrary progression system.  Want to play campaign?  Nope, have to unlock via playing a single battle first.  Want to play Japan in that single battle?  Nope!  Locked!  Want to choose your force for that battle?  hahah no...

I stopped at that point.  I also read that ship classes, maps, campaigns and upgrades are all now locked behind the progression system.  

So basically content I could access (Campaign, full ship & upgrade roster, multiple nations etc) is now unavailable until I grind it open.  

Sorry but that is a terrible decesion in my opinion and pretty much removed my desire to get back into the game and I cannot recommend it at this point.  I do not see the benefit of gating content behind a grind, some of it even only unlocks via MP (of which I have no interest in).  

That being said, prior to the unfortunate update, this was a really good game and I will give some points below for people who do not mind the gating system.  

The game operates on a turn based system with move and fire actions seperate.  Each ship class could be customized with various weaponry giving you a lot of tactical flexibility.  For example a Frigate might have 3 small weapon slots that each have their own aiming cones (area they can fire in) depending on their location on the ship).  Example of weapon systems are light guns, AA guns, Torpedoes etc.  

They balanced the power of weapons quite well.  For example Light Guns could fire every turn, medium guns (on cruisers) could fire every 2 turns, Big Guns (Battleships) every 3, this made the larger ships very powerful but also vulnerable to massed frigate/destroyer torpedo runs which made it necessary to have adequate escorts.  This gave every ship class a proper purpose. 

To fire you have to calculate/estimate distance and direction for guns which while challenging to start you kind of learn distances quite quickly but still meant there was some player skill involved in the actual shooting process.  

In summary, good turn based naval game ruined by a pointless gate/unlock system. If you can live with the unlock system, then it could be worth a shot.

The goal of the system was to help to guide new players through the game and give them goals to achieve, as there is a lot to the game and we saw players getting confused where to start or overwhelmed with the options.

review:
Great game, enjoyed it from the very first moment. The unlocks are perfect for me and serve as an incentive to improve and keep going. The balance and pacing are just right and I find the ship movement and damage modelling to be very believable. This is the kind of battleship game that I have been looking for. 

It is also great that achievements are not dependent on multiplayer, as I really dislike multiplayer. You can get all the achievements with singleplayer missions and campaign, which is FANTASTIC. 

Multiplayer unlocks a handful of extra maps for quick missions, which are non-essential but add a bit of variety, so I might try it just for fun. But it is so nice to have multiplayer as an option, rather than a necessity - my thanks to the developers!

Note: Just finished the whole game in 79 hours and I had so much fun. By the time I finished all campaigns, there was only one achievement left (sink 50 carriers), and it wasn't too much of a grind to sink the remaining 10 or so carriers in quick missions. I thoroughly enjoyed this game and definitely got my money's worth.

review:
This game was on my wishlist for some time so I was quite excited to get it in a bundle. Needless to say, I am glad I did not buy this at anywhere close to full price. It's about as fun as watching paint dry and about as tactical. Worse yet, most of the content is locked even though you pay for the game. 

The elephant in the room is that the game has content locked. Why, in a single player game, is content locked behind skirmishes and winning campaigns (both sides) is one of the dumbest design decisions I've ever run across. For instance, if you want to play the Atlantic campaign then you get to perform the following:

Play at leat one skirmish to unlock the Pacific campaign.
Win the entire campaign as the US.
Win the entire campaign as the Japanese.

There's probably some other MP unlocks in there as well. What is the purpose? Some unlocks are via multiplayer, which is absoutely dead. This fact alone makes the game a massive avoid. Why, for God's sake, would you do that to your customers? If you've worked hard on your game, let your customers actually play it!!!

As for the "gameplay", it's unimaginative and boring. I know that sounds harsh but it is the only way to describe it. The game is a top down version of Worms. You have your ships, sail them around in a turn based map (slowly) and fire away by a combination of picking the direction (this isn't a challenge) and guessing the power (which is like a low-rent version of Worms). You move a small amount, aim, pick your power and fire 2 or 3 times. You then go to your next ship and  do the same thing. You then wait for the AI to do the same with their ships. Repeat ad naseum. That's the game, folks. That's all there is. 

It has none of the charm of Worms and I kid you not that I've played more fun Flash versions of this kind of gameplay. Theres no reward or payoff. Hits are met by dull sound effects and an even duller "explosion" graphic. There's no payoff here for a job well done. It's slow and the only challenge is that it seems the AI ships will always get some sort of advantage. Play the first scenario and your ships have popguns while the enemy ships can fire torpedos that take half your health away. I truly cannot believe how limited this game seems to be.

The scoring system is also more than a bit off. I finished one scenario where I was about to sink the last enemy ship when the timer (why is there a turn limit?) ran out. I lost. For some reason. I have no idea. But worse yet, I don't care. This game isn't worth the time because there's no compelling gameplay.  Guessing at power meters isn't the type of thing that I find entertaining or rewarding. I guess on the positive side is that if you do want a low-rent, charmless, WWII version of Worms then the game works. But unless you have a hankering that specific, then steer clear of this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971948490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1508644788}
review:
Don't believe the World War 2 coat of paint, this is basically a low-effort worms game from a top-down perspective.  You move a unit using a compass and a power meter that forces you to blindly guess at where you're going, then shoot at enemies where direciton is known, but you have to again eyeball the distance.  

Everything is hidden behind a completely ridiculous "Unlock" system, (after already being released and balanced and playtested without it) apparently because Call of Duty made those things popular.  However, instead of unlocking things like battleships after using heavy cruisers or unlocking more modern cruisers after using out-of-date starting ones, you instead unlock the single player campaign by playing multiplayer maps.  Also, multiplayer maps are locked behind single player campaign goals.  So screw your own preferred play style, play the way that the devs mandated!

Multiplayer is basically dead, there's only a half-dozen players online when I look, and they're all in games, so I hope you're prepared to wait around for hours to play a multiplayer game you probably don't want to play, anyway, to unlock the single player maps you presumably do want to play.  

So, starting out, you're stuck with a quick play battle, which might be an OK idea as a no-risk tutorial before a campaign... but then, every option is locked out, so I don't get to select any of my ships. Then, besides one destroyer, I'm stuck with nothing but slow frigates that can't even fire forwards and pea shooter cannons that deal 6 damage to a 300-HP ship. Meanwhile, the enemy gets a cruiser that insta-gibs a ship of mine per turn, has longer range, and gets nothing but criticals, getting a bridge shot killing my destroyer's captain (which is basically the same as sinking the ship) plus a frigate in the first exchange of gunfire.  My completely worthless frigates are completely ineffectual at dealing any damage, which is generally why NOBODY WOULD EVER WANT TO TAKE AN ANTI-SUB ESCORT SHIP INTO A DIRECT SURFACE ENGAGEMENT AND NOBODY WOULD PICK THAT CLASS OF SHIP WILLINGLY, even having their torpedoes (which only fire in a TINY arc basically DIRECTLY behind them while how much you turn when you spin the wheel is PARTLY RANDOMIZED) deal negligible damage to the apparently relatively-god-tier light cruiser.  

The game is also absurdly slow.  You have to stop on your turns constantly because you're completely eyeballing and guessing at everything you do, but the enemy turns take forever as well, as each individual cannon has to get its own individual shot, and each cannon can fire multiple times per turn.  When a torpedo is launched, the game zooms in so close on it that you can't see anything but the featureless water and the torpedo so there isn't even any sense of where the torpedo is or where it's going, plays some pinging active sonar sound (which is absurdly anachronistic on an iron-sights straight-running torpedo), and then either does 2 damage or gets a critical hit and instantly destroys the ship, all on the whims of the RNG. Torpedoes also finish their whole run before anything else gets to move again, and you don't need to worry so much about range since it just travels until it hits something or runs out of range, so aiming torpedoes is LUDICROUSLY easy so long as they're in range and the proper fire arc.  This is "balanced" by making them worthless whenever you use them, but the AI apparently gets crits all day.

Basically, nothing about this game is tactical, it's all about guesstimating distances (which can be an OK gameplay mechanic, if not an exciting one when you have so little variation in weapons), and everything else is just RNG bullshit.  Sure, range guesstimation is partly skill, but I basically figured out how to hit with my second shot, and was hitting with each shot by my third ship, while the AI was routinely missing with its first 1/3rd of its shots, but it still didn't matter, I had the smaller boat.  You win if you get lucky and the game decides to give you the bigger ships that take no damage from littler ships and insta-gib one or two ships a round, and if you get the littler ships, just reset until you do.  I couldn't stomach the single-player enough to even try multiplayer, but so long as you don't get to select your own ships, and ship types have such ludicrous advantages over one another, it still just amounts to whoever the RNG gave the battleship curb-stomping any but the most blind and incompetent range-guesstimators.

Even coming back and re-randomizing things until I get the bigger ship and easily stomp the enemy has no meaning or value, because there's no sense of value or reward, it wasn't my skill that won, it's just the RNG.  There's no gameplay value in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045652927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2065, 'last_played': 1643923465}
review:
I absolutely LOVE this game! It's the first game I've played in years where I didn't mind playing for hours on end.
It may be a little repetitive, but I really felt like I HAD to win. I can play for 20 minutes or lose hours of sleep over it. I can save a game at any time (although I really wish these saved games were saved to Steam instead of locally - my laptop doesn't have the same saved games my desktop does).
Like other reviewers have said, there's no real resource managment, no "politics" involved - just fighting between ships and aircraft. It's more like Risk than about any other game I can think of; you have to have certain types of ships to hold areas you've won; there a "zones" you're trying to take over. You can only move a ship once in a turn so you have to plan carefully. Turns can take as long as you'd like, so there's no rush. If ships are damaged during a battle, they retain that damage even in future battles unless you repair them. To repair them, they have to be in "zones" where a shipyard is without moving for an entire turn. You do earn money based on which properties you control at the end of the turn. You use this money to build more ships which can only originate at specific points. These ships can be customized to some extent when you "build" them.
I love the graphics. The water looks cool, the ships look cool. There are no microtransactions: you buy the game and you're done. Still, I wish there was some DLC.
I really only have a very complaints: damage is determined randomly no matter where you hit another ship. If you hit the rear end, it might still show "bridge damaged" instead of a rudder. It would be neat to be able to zoom completely into your ships during a battle. AI will waste some time barely moving some ships at all, yet taking the time to move them anyway. AI doesn't seem to realize exactly how to correct for its miss. You have NO control over which ships you can move or in what order - sometimes a ship is in the way of another, but you have no choice over which you can move first. It would be neat to have cut scenes of ships being repaired when that happens instead of a bland "3 ships were repaired" text at the top of the screen.
I got the game on sale, but I gotta say it's easily worth $20. Too bad there's no DLC at all. But I love this game.

review:
Ерунда. Корабли одного класса - точная копия друг друга (даже корабли разных наций копии) без уникальных особенностей. Геймплей предельно прост. Торпеды за 1 ход преодолевают максимальное расстояние, то есть не увернуться. Глубинные бомбы оказывается можно кидать с борта эсминца на 1000 метров по ходу движения... господа, это Вторая мировая, здесь ещё не изобрели реактивные бомбомёты, как у современных противолодочных кораблей...
Короче: геймплей скучен, однообразел, лёгок и убог.
Совет: играйте в Atlantic Fleet. То же походавая тактика про флот времен Второй мировой, но гораздо интереснее с уникальными кораблями, которых куча и механикой, которая куда как прогрессивнее.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009586772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1463623279}
review:
This game is very detailed, involves strategic and tactical thinking and rewards it. There is nothing quite like correctly estimating the enemy position and just nailing them. 

However, the down side is that because it is "turn based" and there are so many units, and the AI goes through turns invidividually (which can really suck when AI has like 15 ships) it is a VERY slow game. 

on the strategic map you can see where to move your fleets, guess enemy positions or send planes to scout them it is cool. but the battle phase..literally one match where the enemy attacks you may take almost an hour (and this doesn't even count when game progresses and you are entering into a battle one after another (30-45 min matches x 5 in succession is just sooooo  slow. 

other than the very very slow paced combat, it is fun. I just wish there was an auto option for when your forces are crazy superior to the enemy or vice versa, so you could quick battle that combat and not waste 30 min's on a battle you know you can't lose or alternatively can't win. it just turns into a time sink. 

if they fix this issue, yes get the game. if not, well then do you long tedious drawn out battles where you know the outcome once a match starts? well then look no further as half your battles will involve this.
developer_response:
Hi Moforkus! Jeremy from Mythical City Games here.

I definitely feel you on the speed thing. (I'm a big HoMM / Might and Magic Heroes player and I blast that auto combat all day.) 

When I play Battle Fleet 2, the first thing I do is crank that game speed up to maximum. It speeds things along SIGNIFICANTLY, and if you haven't tried it yet, I highly recommend it. 

Once you're in a match, you'll see a gear icon towards the top right of the screen. In there, there's the "Game Speed" option.

For winning battles, there's no fast solution, but for losing battles, if you hit that gear icon and select "End Mission", you'll lose half of your ships and the territory. In many cases, that might even be better tactically to keep your forces up.

Hope that helps! We're happy you liked the core of the game, and with some speed improvements, that you'll continue to enjoy Battle Fleet 2.

Jeremy
Mythical City Games

review:
I never write a review on Steam but this little gem deserves to be the first!

A great game for the casual player - with online options for those who like that (not me)

The game is very easy to learn, although I still need to learn how to prevent my submarines to crash onto Islands ;)

Every ship has it's own characteristics, giving the game a historical flavor, without making it complicated for the player. Aiming is partly done by being accurate and partly by your skill of guessing the distance. This makes that when you hit it feels like YOU achieved something, making the sinking of an enemy ship feel like a victory.

The game starts with just a few options to play, but soon enough new options will become available. I was worried about the online games I needed to play to open specific options, but just one message to the developer made him opening these parts of the game for me (during Xmas none the less!!!).

When you are looking for a fun little game on the side, with historical units/maps and a bit of  simulation - then this is game you should not miss. You wont be dissapointed!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986102901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1482441284}
review:
First no support for resolutions greater than 1080p.  

Secondly to unlock single player maps, specifically Wake Islands and Australia you need to obtain online wins.  The ability to play as Japan or Germany first requires you to win as America (for Japan) or the UK for Germany.  Not just the Japanese and German campaigns, but to even use them in a quick battle (one off skirmish vs the AI).  I bought this during the winter sale thinking I'd launch it and get to have some fun a campaign marauding around the Pacific on the Yamato, but nope that's locked away.  You can't even start a campaign without playing other gamemodes first.  From the description about picking your own fleet, playing with weapons, etc. I was expecting much more freedom to set up a naval chess match however I wanted, instead I launched and found myself staring at a menu with 80% of the options greyed out.  It's an annoying arbitrary decision, I can launch into a battle as the USN, give myself max industrial points and run around but if I want to try another faction's hardware I have to grind. Refunded.

As a later edit, I did some browsing on the Steam Forums and apparently these locks only came into place in a recentish update.  Others have taken to the forums to complain.  Apparently if you sign up for an account on the dev's forums and email the dev team, they'll unlock the game for you.  They can also do one time unlocks sans account (but if you reinstall later all the locks come back).  It's a few too many hoops for me, maybe I'll check back during the Summer Sale and if they've patched the locks back out.

review:
Básicamente es un juego de acertar calculando la distancia del disparo, pero toda la parafernalia que tiene alrededor hace que sea más interesante de lo que patece.

A favor:
- Bastantes tipos de unidades (acorazado, crucero, destructor, fragata,  portaaviones, submarinos, transportes, baterías costeras y aeropuertos). Además, muchos barcos del mismo tipo son distintos entre si.
-  La disposición de las armas en los barcos hace que puedas disparar con ellas según la posición del enemigo.
- Campaña estratégica.
- Las animaciones son gustosas: los cañonazos, los disparos de torpedos y los hundimientos, sobre todo.
- Es posible distribuir el armamento en los barcos nuevos.

En contra:
- Como simulación realista no tiene nada. Unos pocos destructores pueden destruir un acorazado a cañonazos.
- Puede hacerse un poco repetitivo.
- El despliegue aleatorio en las batallas es nefasto. Igual te encuentras con que el portaaviones aparece a tiro de las baterías costeras.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 7757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5156, 'last_played': 1641420829}
review:
D'accord c'est une appli pour tablette, d'accord le niveau stratégique est aussi séduisant qu'un plateau de Risk d'il y a 40 ans., d'accord c'est mou au posssible, d'accord le réalisme est aux abonnés absents, d'accord l'IA est aux fraises... n'empêche, il y a plein de petits détails qui font que ce jeu est un petit bijou tactique.

En vrac ce que j'aime bien :

L'assistance au tir est limitée, (quelques cercles de distance) donc à moins d'avoir vraiment le compas dans l'oeil à chaque tour se pose la question du compromis entre tirs de réglages et tirs pour faire mal.

Les navires ont des emplacements tourelles aux arcs de tir bien différenciés, lors de gros engagements chaque mouvement est un casse-tête d'orientation pour optimiser les tirs.

Lors de l'achat d'un navire les tourelles sont dans une certaine mesure paramétrables : un petit croiseur tout canon, un peu d'AA ou de lance-torpille ? Chaque type de tourelle ayant des caractéristique dégâts, fréquence de tir, portée, les choix ne sont pas si anodins qu'il y parait.

La navigation aussi est laissé entièrement à la charge du joueur et le risque de collision est réel. La aussi compromis à trouver entre position idéale et risque de taper le voisin ou les hauts fonds.

Collision aussi lors de tirs dont les trajectoires tiennent compte de l'élévation. Vous tirez tendu par dessus un allié, il en prend plein la tête. Vous vous collez à une ile, c'est la colline qui déguste, pas la cible de l'autre côté. Ca marche aussi pour l'IA, ce qui veut dire que l'on peut utiliser le terrain comme écran. Bon, il y a des effets pervers du décor destructible rigolos mais pas très réalistes comme dégommer une batterie cotiêre trop près de la plage à la torpille ou creuser un lac salé au milieu d'une ile^^

Sympa aussi les effets de zone. Les gros obus peuvent faire mal même en tombant à côté. Dans certains cas on peut toucher plusieurs navires avec la même salve. Pareil pour les attaques aériennes, une bonne orientation peut impacter plusieurs cibles très proches. A noter que plus les navires sont proches, plus la DCA est forte. Le placement défensif est aussi important que l'offensif.

La visibilité de la fumée des dégats à travers le brouillard de guerre. D'un point de vue principe de brouillard de guerre ça parait crétin et je ne suis pas sur que ce soit voulu mais sur l'océan une fumée ça se voit, alors ça m'a bien plu.

Ce que j'ai fini par apprécier :

Le non positionnement initial.  Au départ ça m'a vraiment saoûlé, se retrouver avec un croiseur AA à l'opposé de la flotte de l'autre côté d'une ile qu'il mettra 10 tours à contourner... pfff. Mais à l'usage j'ai fini par trouver que ça rajoute à l'ambiance et à la reflexion. On se retrouve dans une situation pas si irréaliste où les flotilles arrivent un peu en vrac au rappel sur un contact et les premiers tours consistent à organiser tout ça sans se retrouver dans une position déplorable. Tactiquement ça a du sens.

Ce qui pose problème :

La difficulté n'est pas au rendez-vous. L'IA est faiblarde et à tendance à s'éparpiller dans des flottes légères. Le niveau le plus élevé lui donne une capacité à faire mouche quasi à tout coup mais ne la rend pas plus intelligente. Ca ne m'a pas gêné, jouer avec comme objectif personnel de prendre le moins de dégâts possibles me suffit. Ca doit bien donner en multi, mais je joue en solo et je n'ai aucune idée de sa fréquentation.

Le réalisme est minimal. A part  les noms des navires et des lieux, comment dire...  c'est un jeu quoi. Personnellement ça m'a satisfait car j'y ai trouvé une vrai ambiance de combat naval dans les questions tactiques à se poser mais c'est vrai qu'il y a pas mal de choses qui pourraient être mieux.
Les vaisseaux d'un type sont tous les mêmes (7 catégories du cargo au porte-avions).
Je n'ai pas trouver comment les renommer donc au bout d'un moment on a des transports machin, machin 1....,
Les flottes initiales des campagnes sont à peu près cohérentes mais après quelques tours ça devient vite n'importe quoi.
Vous pouvez finir un cuirassé avec la pétoire de pont d'un cargo (bah oui c'est le lot de tous les jeux qui modélisent des points de vie, lequel d'entre nous n'a jamais fini un dragon émeraude à coup de fourche de paysan ?).
Le brouillard de guerre est un peu pipeau dans la mesure où le jeu nous montre le tour adverse.
La détection des sous-marin en plongée profonde par les avions de reco est un peu "too much" pour la période mais justifiée par l'équilibre du jeu (j'ai l'impression que les sous-marins posent toujours un problème en tour par tour, la furtivité associée à la puissance de tir conduisant direct à l'écueil du one-shot sorti de nulle part tout aussi irréaliste).

Un dernier mot sur l'aspect contextuel subjectif. J'ai repris ce jeu que son look peu engageant m'avait fait laisser de côté en sortant de Victory At Sea avec lequel je me suis ennuyé à mourir tellement il est répétitif, irréaliste et d'un néant tactique abyssal dès que l'on a un porte-avion. Tactiquement le contraste était tellement flagrant que je me suis plongé à fond dans Battle Fleet 2 en passant sur tous ses défauts (j'aurais tendance à penser qu'inversement si on aime Victory At Sea, on va vraiment avoir du mal avec Battle Fleet 2). J'aurais bien tenté Fleet Command mais je n'ai pas réussi à le faire tourner correctement sur ma config et, en  tour par tour qui se veut plus réaliste, Atalantic Fleet m'a donné une bonne première impression mais j'ai coincé sur l'équilibrage destroyer/sous-marin assez surprenant.

Edit: j'ai repris ce jeu après une longue pause et un patch à corrigé les effets pervers du décor destructible, on ne peut plus terraformer les îles à grands coups de torpille ou de 356 de marine. Logique et, en même temps, je suis un peu déçu : le froid réalisme a une fois de plus terrassé l'absurdité poétique ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198039222800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 5852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5820, 'last_played': 1479176923}
review:
Now six years later I thought I would take a look one last time at a now classic turn based game. If you remember the old Panzer General series games or if you loved Naval tactical games. Then Battle Fleet 2 may be for you. Let's take one last look at what Battlefleet 2 did well and what they can do to improve if they continue the series.
PROS
Game play: Let's face it. You don't need much for great naval fun. It has a lot to offer for the price. Great Carriers, subs, destroyers, planes, all on an overhead risk type map. Solid sounds, effects, colors, layouts, all you need to get started.
Gimmick: At the time of creative applications. BF2 introduced fun Strategic Cards as bonuses that could turn the battle in your favor. In today's trade card collector game market, not a bad little gimmick that works.
Controls: Damage is handled great in this game and the compass targeting and some fun features make the confrontations fun instead of 2 vs 2 affairs you could wind up with massive battles.
Updates: This game was constantly updated and added to with VR and other mechanical changes that showed the passion behind the maker. Always a plus. 
Price: It is not a grand strategy naval game, but feels like one. Battleship in a store is more and gives you much less. 
CONS
Spacing: Maneuvering is an issue, so careful of collisions. The map always felt crowded and restrictive. 
Depth: The lack of scope can make it too simple for those who like massive campaigns. 
Coding: The AI gets obvious in the two campaign modes. It becomes more about out numbering the front line than actual strategy in the tactical map.
Firing: Figuring out Targeting from long distances can be tricky and falling behind the AI with hit/ misses can be a killer, but you will adjust. 

My Final Word: It's great seas battles at a low cost. The mechanics are simple to easy to pick up. This has become a very cult favorite among turn base lovers. It is what I call advanced battleship. A missed opportunity to be Pacific Storm or KoeI's PTO, having more additional Strategic abilities and more scope to it, however for the price. This is a fun game to have.  Please see the VIDEO above discussion to see if the game play if for you before buying. It will be interesting to see the next version of BF2, up against the likes of World of Warships, Cold Waters, and other more advanced presentations, but Mythical City proves that game play still rules no matter the graphical prowess of a developer. SIx years after still holds up, and good clean fun still works. 
My final grade: 3.3 out of 5 stars

author: {'steamid': '76561198066311208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1536916079}
review:
Good:
1. Could have many big fleets. Each map allows 24 ships in max.
2. Customized shipboard weapons.
3. Easy to learn, easy to play.
4. Control firing by ourself.
5. Real ship moves, included turning speed, turning curve, slowly backward and.....collide! (beware your ships collide would hurt your ships a lot)
6. Ship names are random, but historical.
7. Quick game play, move-fire in the battlefield; move fleets and save money for ships in strategy map.
8. AI cheats depend on diffculty, harder AI could peform "call shot" or "100% hit" and move first at battlefields. AI could put stronger ships against player's weak side.


Bad: 
1. Few ships models, all ships at same class have same looks.(Yamato and Nelson shared similar shapes)
2. Standardized weapons, all battleship guns are called "heavy turret" in game. For IJN, no Longlance(Type 93) torpedos.
3. Few types of ship, only 7 of them.  Bigger ships have their weapon slots fewer than historical.
4. No armor protection, fragile battleships. Light guns(for FF, DD, CV and Trans) does normal damage against bigger ships. Battleships heavy turrets could easily been destoryed. 
5. Small map for warfields and fewer maps for world, the game would finished quickly at lower diffculty. Each battlefield had contained so huge area that larger than a medium country, biggest map is Australia, that's counted as 1.
6. VERY WEAK carrier airstrike. VERY easliy defeat by ship AAs. That've made Pacific War looks so ridiculous. Kamikazes would never had a chance to got Allies ships in this game.
7. NO DEPLOYMENT at entering battlefield. That's HELPFUL for AI's cheat.


優點: 
1. 可以有很多艦隊,而且每張地圖最高可以編組24艘船的艦隊.(不過玩家很難存那麼多錢)
2. 自己安排新船艦上配備的武器.
3. 易學易玩,很適合戰略遊戲的新手.
4. 自己管理火控和機動
5. 真實化的船艦機動,包括轉彎速度,迴轉半徑,慢速後退.....還有小心碰撞,自己的船開場就撞到很傷的.
6. 艦名是隨機的,但史實上確有其船.
7. 節奏在回合制遊戲算明快,戰場上就是移動船艦和攻擊指示; 戰略地圖上是移動艦隊和存錢買船.
8. 電腦作弊看難度決定,高難度電腦作弊可以指定摧毀玩家的船上部件,100%砲擊命中率,加上絕對的先動權. 另外電腦可以決定開場船艦的部署,以便於直接抓掉玩家的弱邊.

缺點:
1. 船艦模型相當少,所有同等船艦都只有相同外觀.(大和級和尼爾森級看起來會相同嗎?)
2. 武裝極度標準化, 砲就只有輕中重三種. 魚雷也全部一致化(對,日本的93式魚雷被拔掉了)
3. 船艦類型不多,只有七種. 大船上的武器欄位比史實上要少很多.
4. 沒有裝甲.導致戰艦和巡洋艦變的脆弱不堪,(加上大船的HP被低估許多); 戰艦主砲塔很容易被擊毀,驅逐艦隊也可以用其主砲擊毀戰艦.
5. 戰場地圖太小,而世界地圖畫分的區域太少也太大; 最大的區域如澳洲加上其海域,幾乎跟整個美國一樣大. 在低難度時玩家可以很快結束一場戰役.
6. 航空母艦的機隊虛弱不堪,就算是落單的驅逐艦防空砲高射砲也可以以擊退. 如果防空砲真的那麼強,那麼太平洋戰爭怎麼不是砲戰比較多???
7. 玩家不能決定進入戰場時的船艦位置,而電腦可以.
8.高難度狀況下你可以看到各種鬼扯蛋的牛大便等級作弊. 
如果低難度你覺的自己是山本五十六加上米內光政上身,那高難度你會以為自己是南雲忠一的能力和小澤治三郎的運氣.

review: Great game, no keyboard input, total control by mouse, I enjoy playing it after finally understanding how it all works. It takes a little experimentation to figure it out.  The skill is in timing, angular positions and movement and estimating distance to target. You can target specific areas of a ship if you know the distance.  After 50 hours there are still a few unknowns like - the order of turns from ship to ship - it is predetermined and you do not get to pick which individual ship goes next be it Allies or Axis. Care must be taken in moving as you can collide with friendlies or enemy alike, the AI even has collisions. I am not sure I like the floating rewards in the water where the first one to get close to it gets the prize be it a free recon, air strike, repair a ship or put out an array of mines.  Perhaps if they could be turned off as an option.  As soon as I think I have mastered this game I look forward to my first multiple player experience. Last, it is really fast at saving the game but you are forced to exit the game at that time and while you get put back to the exact circumstances on restart the last range finder setting is lost for the last ship to ship encounter, a really minor annoyance. Overall, the replayability is great, it is a lot of fun and you are never rushed to do anything.  The highest of 3 difficulty modes is a challenge to most gamers. If you like fleet level WWII sea battles you'll like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027968359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1463287086}
review:
[h1] Game Mechanics [/h1]

Combat is turn-based, requiring manual control of ship movement and aiming/firing weapons. You need to estimate the firing range of enemy targets (except when firing torpedoes or launching Airstrikes).

There are 7 ship weapon types in the game (Depth Charges, Torpedo, Anti-Aircraft gun, Deck Gun, Standard Turret, Medium Turret, Heavy Turret).

Each weapon type has a certain firing arc, does a certain number of damage points (varies slightly in actual use during combat), has a certain maximum firing range, has a certain number of guns (if any), and has a certain number of times that it can fire each combat turn.

Some territories are defended with a certain number of Coastal Artillery and/or an Airfield that need to be destroyed before the territory can be conquered.

Each territory requires the attacking fleet to have a certain minimum number of transport ships (if any) in order to be able to conquer that territory.

Each turn, you earn Prestige Points equal to the value of all of the territories under your control.

You spend Prestige Points to build ships in any territory with a shipyard that is under your control.

There are 7 ship types in the game (Transport, Submarine, Frigate, Destroyer, Cruiser, Battleship, Carrier).

Each ship type has a certain number of certain weapon types that are mounted in certain fixed directions (either Fore, Port, Starboard, Mid (i.e. can fire to either port or starboard), or Aft).

Each ship type has a certain number of Hit Points, a certain maximum movement range per combat turn, a certain turning radius, and certain abilities (depth charges, sub detection, recon aircraft, squadron aircraft, territory capture).

Each ship type has a Bridge, an Engine, a Rudder, and Ammunition (the Carrier also has a Flight Deck) that each have their own individual Hit Points.

Squadron Aircraft from Carriers can perform 1 of 3 possible action types (either Defend, Recon, or Airstrike).


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

If you like very slow-paced, turn-based tactical movement and combat, and having to estimate firing ranges of targets, then you will enjoy this computer game.

Personally, I think that this computer game is okay but I can't recommend this computer game because it is too slow-paced for my liking, I don't like the way that aircraft function from aircraft carriers, and I really don't like having to manually estimate the firing range of targets.

I recommend that you buy, install, and play the naval combat computer game Victory At Sea instead which has a lot more ship types and, in my opinion, is a superior and more realistic naval combat computer game.

I waited until it went on sale, but it's totally worth the money. I'm an older dude at 30 and I grew up with the old "set the angle, set the power, then fire" games in the 90's. This is like that but with better graphics. What I really like is the ability to damage specific systems. For example, I've only played a few battles but one I was murderously outgunned by the Americans. However, my little ships fired specifically, and accurately, at the cruisers main guns taking them out and defanging it. It was very satisfying.

The campaigns are reminiscent of Axis and Allies and well, not sure what else to say. It's turn based, it has many ships and a rudementary economy. You aim and fire your own shots with luck and intuition to guide you. If that sounds kind of fun, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001912496', 'num_games_owned': 1615, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1559351437}
review:
Here we have "Battle Fleet 2", with a campaign map that actually reminds me of my model battles on carpet, while a part strategy game, part battle simulator that takes me back to imaginary duels I had my model ships as a kid. Distance is calculated not with rulers or yard sticks, but with the imagination and a slight advantage of range circles. Battles are fought by turn and the actions played out in real time, and there is nothing more agonising than watching your painfully 'calculated' shots fall short or long. Thankfully, you can speed up gameplay so these moments are short-lived.
It took me a while to get around to playing this tremendous title for the simple omission of an in-battle save feature, as believe me the battles can and do go on. Ironically, since this has been addressed and there is indeed an in-battle save feature now, I tend to complete the battle...it's that "Just one more turn" phenomenon known so well to turn-based gamers.
So, you have the Campaign Map, where you plan your advances, reinforcements, build cues and assaults. Then when battle is joined, you go to the top-down tactical map. One immersion-breaker is the use of "Strategic Command Cards to surprise your enemies with special actions like deploying mines, sabotage, enhanced aiming, airstrikes and more!", as while these are fun to use, the enemy AI always without fail makes a beeline for them instead of their objective. In fact it becomes a race to pick up cards. That aside, you attack, defend and send airstrikes against the enemy, and there is nothing more satisfying than pulling a hopeless situation from the jaws of defeat into a tactical withdrawal by the enemy with only a shore gun and a lone destroyer sinking an enemy battleship, starting a panic in the AI. Transports I still don't understand. They are obviously important for holding acquired territory, but just clutter the battle map and waste time getting them the Hell out of Dodge. Perhaps they could have been left from the battle, and their loss rate simulated instead based on victory/defeat conditions (as done in "Victory At Sea").
While not as attractive nor immediate as "Atlantic Fleet", this is a far more engrossing and long lasting game for naval enthusiasts. If you re even mildly interested in W II naval conflict, and would like to test your skills from Admiral down to gunner...pick this up. You won't regret the hours lost playing this fine strategy simulator.

review: Wargames are still alive on Steam. I really like old school, tactical wargames with some decent graphics, a good dose of action, and non-heavy strategy (not so much into base building or building up my empire or civilisation). Battle Fleet 2 is a fun game. The graphics are pretty ordinary but moving your fleet around while trying to torpedo the enemy fleet is exciting. The single player campaign is quite good which you can't say about many games. The AI attacks you strongly and in my last battle the enemy zoned in on my carrier and sunk it with the minimum of fuss despite my attempts to stop it. I haven't tried multiplayer yet but this kind of game would be very good to play against friends. It is quite simple to play and a great way to relax for a few hours.

review:
What can I say it's a great strategy game. If you dislike strategy games then it's probably not for you. 

But you're here reading these so I highly doubt that's the case. There's a good amount of variety and with online multiplayer battles you can easily sink a ton of hours in. 

Everything works really well, I've seen a few other reviews say it but the game runs really smooth and has very few issues. The graphics are great and the sound effects really draw you in. There's a ton of strategy and tactics trying to outmaneuver the enemy fleet and setup a proper ambush to run them over.

I do wish there was more to the game and it's certainly not perfect but I had a lot of fun.

It's a pretty low cost so give it a shot. I'm sure you wont be disappointed.

review:
Battlefleet 2 has a quality about it similar to Civilization 5. You want to keep on playing.

When I sunk my first ship, I was ecstatic. When I crushed the a Japanese fleet trying to move in on my territory, I was so happy. This game is awesome.

The thing that sets it apart is the turn order. You don’t do your moves and then the other player does their own. Rather you move ships in a set order. You may move 4 ships in a row and then your opponent moves 3. I’ve never seen this before in a turn based strategy game.

Also torpedoes are so satisfying.

Highly recommend.

review:
I just finished the pacific campaign and must say this game is pretty entertaining. It is definitely worth considering if you are a fan of naval warfare. I would recommend it at a good sale price personally but i'm for sure going to get my monies worth out of it in terms of dollars for hours played. 

The game play is quite easy to pick up. The japs worked me the first campaign I played but by the second time through I had picked up enough to be able rule the waves.

The graphics aren't anything special but this game isnt about the graphics, its about naval strategy and being able to calculate how far away an enemy ship is based on a 2000 meter circle and the fall of your shot. The having to calculate and figure out just what bearing and distance to put on a shot is what got me for this game.

I give it a 7.5/10 and I hope all the potential buyers out there enjoy this game as much as I do.

review:
What a entertaining little game.

It runs perfectly on a "office" toaster - meaning the absolute non-gaming rig. It is turn based so one can leave it running and do turns whenever there's a hole in the schedule, during lunch break, coffee timeouts etc.

It is a mirrored setup wargame with no asymmetry, meaning all nations have access to the same ships with the same capabilities. This leads to a very "alternative" version of nations but it is by no means a deterrent. Quite funny to see Nazi Germany with a fleet of carriers...

I like the "scorched earth" mechanics although it has ample space for further development - IMO the torpedoes should not be fire and forget but rather arm them for a distance.

All in all a great buy and great "little" game with extensive replayability.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970911993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1432083582}
review:
Hey, Harpoon it's not. But then again who has the time to invest ina game like Harpoon. Battle Fleet 2 is a mix of fun, some light strategy, a little bit of tactical thinking and the satisfaction of watching your salvos hit the mark. It isn't for someone that wants total immersion, but it does give us elements of everything that one needs to to lose themselves in the S Pacific or Atlantic while waiting for the kids to get home from school or on that boring flight to Tampa for business. 

Historically accurate, up to a point and interesting enough to hold the attention of a military history student such as myself, I think that the developer has hit the right mix to appeal to someone who otherwise might not purchase or be inclined to play a war game on any level. Furthermore, the developers do care about what the customers say...more than I can say for some companies. 

Pros:

Fun 
Decent Enough Graphics and Sound
Some Good History 
Engaging, but not demanding
Has replayability

Cons:

Not deep enough to appeal to real military hounds
Feels a little 'appy'


Overall, This gets my thumbs up for the way it can fill in the void of stupid apps to a pretty darn serious PC gamer like me. Like I said before: Fun, Engaging enough and fills the niche left between dumb apps and super serious strategy.

2. the campain is too simple and has funny things, like allowing capturing the whole pacific with a single frigate.

review:
Picking up inexpensive games during Steam sales is always a roll of a dice. This one was a pair of 6's.

This is a fun, top-down tactical wargame. While there is no tutorial, one really isn't needed since the controls are intuitive. Movement is done in turns, with one "move" and one "attack" command available per turn. Fog of war is present, so some "attack" moves have to be used for the purposes of recon.

Attacking is done by way of aiming various weapons (guns of several different sizes, torpedos, depth charges, etc) and then setting their range. Near-misses do small amounts of damage, just as they would in reality. It can be nerve-wracking to watch your opponent shoot at you multiple times during a turn, each round coming closer and closer and closer...

There are standalone battles, custom battles that you can create on your own, campaigns, and a multiplayer system. I have not tried the latter yet, but the single-player portion has been quite addictive, and is definitely recommendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998740055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1434344312}
review:
This is what I would refer to as a good "laptop - airport" game. What I mean by that is that its a good offline game that I imagine most laptops could handle and can kill a fair amount of time while waiting at an airport, or the like. Its not bad, but there is still a fair bit left to be desired so I could only recomend this as a on the cheap game.

The parts that I like most is the gameplay mechanics. Having to use your brain and calculate distances by dead-reckoning brings a good level of strategy into the game. I also like how all new ships are customizeable, at least to a point. Plus having various parts of a ship destructable adds a good touch.

The main point that I did not care for as much was the point system to fund new construction. I found it to be too limited and too difficult to save up points for high-teir ships. Additionally, I felt that the speed of the ships were lacking, and it made it tedious to get fleets into a good matchup. To follow up with this complaint I did not like how the game auto-deploys the fleet, usually spreading your ships all over the map without much rhyme or reason (at least to my mind).

This is not by any means a high-paced action game, this is a sit-down thinker and for some people this game should be a good match. For everyone else, it is probably something to walk away from. Personally, I will probably put in a few hours into it here and there still so I will recomend it for that reason.

review:
Очень несложная, но неплохая пошаговая стратегия в декорациях тихоокеанских сражений времён Второй мировой. К "симулятору", как написано в метках, отношение имеет весьма отдалённое, но этого тут и не требуется. Корабли делятся на условные классы ("крейсер", "фрегат", "подлодка"), отличаются количеством точек установки вооружения, скоростью да живучестью. За один ход в бою каждый корабль может переместиться и стрелять любым количеством орудий, при стрельбе есть одна особенность - необходимо указывать расстояние до цели, при том, что линейки нет (есть вспомагательные круги-радиусы, отключаемые на высоких уровнях сложности). Получатся, что в начале каждого хода необходимо пристреливаться - а на точный огонь стреляющих башен может уже и не хватить. Так как каждая башня имеет свои сектора обстрела, необходимо продумывать на несколько ходов вперёд, как бы удачнее развернуться так, чтобы обеспечить большую плотность огня по целям. Ничего сложного в этом нет, но получается занятно. Стратегическая чать тоже очень простая, каждый ход строим корабли и перемещаемся по одной клетке-зоне за ход к враженским флотам, встертились - воюем, всё.
В общем, неплохая и простая в освоении пошаговая стратегия.

review:
Lovely little game of turn based battles and turn based campaign.  No twitchy features at all are a huge boost in this game.  What stands out about it is the 'worms-like' firing mechanic.  Hitting and missing is about careful judgement of range, which definitely gets easier to judge as you play more.

There are some defnite downsides to this game, the main one being there is only one campaign to play, the pacific.  Other things are the ship customisation doesn't seem to remember what you chose last time, though that may be an option somewhere I missed, and finally, that guns are a bit more powerful than perhaps they shoiuld be, and torps a bit weaker.  

None of those things detract from the overall effect of a really nice, simple, cheap game, playable in half hour bursts.  

Great for the price, 5/5

review:
[h1]“Una buen Marina no es una provocación a la guerra. Es la mejor garantía de paz. 8.4/10“[/h1]

Battle Fleet 2 es la secuela de un titulo que nunca salió de las plataformas de Apple, Battle Fleet nos permitía comandar intensas batallas marítimas por turnos. Debido al éxito que cosechó la primera entrega en la App Store el equipo responsable de Battle Fleet decidió lanzar una segunda entrega, esta vez a través de diferentes plataformas, por lo que podemos conseguirlo a través de la App Store, Google Play o Steam.

El sistema jugable en Battle Fleet 2 es simple, tu flota constará de diferentes clases de naves y submarinos, cada uno con armamento y alcance diferentes y habilidades que te ayudarán en combate.

Para mover a tu flota y atacar consta de una interfaz simple, que permite apuntar con precisión en base a distancia y potencia. Al igual que hemos visto en juegos como Worms, el sistema de combate se basa en su mayoría en una serie continua de “intento y error” por lo que generalmente no atinarás al primer intento.

Cada tiro que aciertas correctamente sobre un enemigo tendrá la posibilidad de dañar o inhabilitar permanentemente alguna de sus funciones, ya sea terminar con su armamento principal o dañar sus motores y controles para restarles maniobrabilidad y evitar que huya.

En Battle Fleet 2 ten encontrarás con gran variedad de naves bajo tu control, todas con diferentes características y tamaños, que van desde una pequeña y veloz fragata a un potente crucero de combate e incluso portaaviones que facilitan la batalla, cada una tiene su propio alcance y potencia por lo que seguramente terminarás utilizando las que más se ajusten a tu forma de jugar.

[h1]Pros:[/h1] [list]
[*]Una excelente toma en el género de estrategia.
[*]A pesar de la carencia de contenido, el juego otorga una inmensa re-jugabilidad debido a lo intensas que llegan a ser algunas batallas..
[*]Un Inteligencia Artificial dura y bien trabajada.
[*]Casi tan adictivo como la cocaína pero mucho más barato. (Las drogas son malas.) [/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1] [list]
[*]Carece de contenido y campañas que lo hagan aún más re-jugable.
[*]El sistema de movimiento necesita trabajo para evitar colisiones. [/list]

[h1]Conclusión:[/h1]
Battle Fleet 2 es un juego impresionante, es en extremo divertido y adictivo, llega a hacerte pensar en muchas ocasiones y es perfecto para ocupar una tarde entera. Si eres fan de la estrategia y buscas entretenimiento para una tarde (o varias) no dudes en comprar Battle Fleet 2, es perfecto desde donde lo mires, ya sea que lo juegues en móvil o PC. Totalmente recomendado.
